journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: A numerical investigation of moment coefficient and flow structure in a rotor–stator cavity with rotor-mounted bolts

article-meta.aff: 1Thermo-Fluid Mechanics Research Centre, University of Sussex, Brighton, UK
2School of Engineering and Mathematical Science, City University London, London, UK

author-notes.corresp: Abdulnaser Sayma, School of Engineering and Mathematical Science, City University London, London EC1V 0HB, UK. Email: a.sayma@city.ac.uk

abstract.p: The torque associated with overcoming the losses on a rotating disc is of particular importance to the designers of gas turbine engines. Not only does this represent a reduction in useful work, but it also gives rise to unwanted heating of metal surfaces and the adjacent fluid. This article presents a numerical study on the effect of rotor-mounted bolts on the moment coefficient and velocity distributions within a rotor–stator cavity under conditions representative of modern gas turbine engine design. Steady-state, two-dimensional and three-dimensional, computational fluid dynamics simulations are obtained using the FLUENT commercial code with a standard k–ɛ turbulence model. The model is validated against experimental data and then used to investigate the effects of varying the number of bolts and also a continuous ring. Two test cases are investigated: one corresponds to where the flow structure is dominated by the superimposed flow (λT = 0.35); and the other, where rotation is expected to govern the flow structure (λT = 0.35). The principal flow phenomena in the vicinity of the bolts were described using the simulation results. Increasing the number of bolts will decrease the relative total pressure difference around bolts and increase the tangential velocity of the core of fluid between the rotor and stator. It was also found out that the free-stream Reynolds number of the flow approaching the bolts decreases and angle of attack increases with increasing number of bolts. As a consequence, the bolts’ wake character changes leading to a situation where the wake of one bolt is not fully collapsed in advance of the following bolt. The occurrence of Taylor columns were also investigated in the rotor–stator system with rotor-mounted bolts. It was found that while increasing the number of bolts can decrease the Rossby number to produce an intermediate rotation in the system, the Taylor columns will not be produced even for 60 bolts under the both flow conditions. The contribution of skin friction to the overall moment coefficient reduces as the number of bolts increases and the pressure-related losses increase. Increasing the number of bolts will decrease the moment produced by each individual bolt. However, since there are more bolts in the system the total moment of all bolts will increase by increasing their number. There also appears to be a point where increasing the number of bolts does not bring about an increase in the overall moment coefficient. It is also interesting to report that the moment coefficient associated with a continuous ring is similar to that for a plain disc.

sec.title: Introduction and review of previous work
sec.p: Increasing the specific power output of a gas turbine engine, and consequently reducing the size of the power plant, requires a higher turbine entry temperature of the main gas flow accompanied by a higher pressure ratio. Turbine entry temperatures in modern civil engines are currently above 1600 ℃, and components in contact with a flow at such high temperatures will rapidly exceed their creep and fatigue limits leading to catastrophic failure. It is only possible to operate at these elevated temperatures because of the internal air system which uses some of the compressor air to cool the turbine discs, blades and nozzle guide vanes. However, air used for cooling will be heated as a result of viscous dissipation as it flows over both rotating and stationary surfaces. A torque needs to be provided to overcome these irreversible losses and this parasitic phenomenon is referred to as windage. Skin friction will be the source of windage for a smooth surface. However, it is not uncommon for protrusions such as bolts to be attached to the rotating and stationary surfaces. In this case, form drag will also contribute to windage. More accurate predictions of windage offer potential for improved design of the internal air system, with associated increases in thrust and efficiency. It is worth noting that there will also be a torque associated with the so-called pumping losses which occur as a result of the work done by a protrusion changing the angular momentum of the fluid. It is important to make the distinction between these and windage because the pumping loss term is isentropic. The sum of the irreversible torque (due to windage) and the reversible torque (due to pumping work) is embodied in the moment coefficient which is defined in equation (3).

Early investigations of frictional losses due to rotating discs were carried out by Daily and Nece1 and Bayley and Owen.2 These investigations identified a number of relevant dimensionless parameters. For a disc of outer radius, b, rotating at an angular velocity ω, in a fluid of density ρ and dynamic viscosity μ, supplied with a superimposed mass flow rate m·, the torque is M. The rotational Reynolds number Reφ, dimensionless flow rate Cw and moment coefficient Cm are defined as (1)Reφ=ρωb2μ (2)Cw=m·μb (3)Cm=M12ρω2b5 For an axial gap between the rotating disc and a stationary casing of s, the gap ratio G is defined as (4)G=sb

The flow structure and dependence of the moment coefficient are determined by the flow regime. For no superimposed flow, Cw = 0, the regimes identified by Daily and Nece are: (1) small G, laminar flow; (2) large G, laminar flow; (3) small G, turbulent flow and (4) large G, turbulent flow. The interested reader is referred to either the original work or to Figure 6.1 of Owen and Rogers3 for more information. As a rough guide, the flow is turbulent for Reφ>105 and for turbulent flow, G is considered to be large when G > 0.04.

As noted by Owen and Rogers3, the presence of superimposed radial flow complicates the boundaries between these regimes. In particular, a large superimposed flow can cause the flow to be turbulent even when there is no rotation. For the applications reflected in this article, the flow is expected to be turbulent and for the geometries analysed G = 0.1. Consequently, the description that follows below applies to a turbulent flow regime with a large axial gap.

For no superimposed flow, Cw = 0, the flow structure comprises separate boundary layers on the rotor and stator and a central core region where there is only tangential motion with about 40% of disc speed. Flow is pumped up the rotor and moves radially inward down the stator. For the case of a superimposed radial flow (Cw > 0), increasing the superimposed flow reduces the tangential velocity of the core. For small amounts of superimposed flow, the flow structure in the cavity is dominated by rotation; conversely for large amounts, the flow structure is dominated by the superimposed flow. Owen and Rogers3 developed a useful parameter to delineate these two regimes. The turbulent flow parameter λT takes its definition from a momentum integral solution of the boundary layer equations using the one-seventh power law velocity profile4 (5)λT=CwReφ0.219

Owen and Rogers3 also considered the more general case of a rotating disc in a rotating fluid. This is a good approximation to the flow behaviour in an unshrouded rotor–stator system where the axial gap between the discs exceeds boundary layer thickness. The flow entrained by the rotor is given by (6)Cw,ent=ɛmReφ0.8 where the coefficient ɛm depends on the core rotation factor β. For λT < ɛm, the flow structure is dominated by rotation and for λT > ɛm, the throughflow dominates. There is no simple closed-form relationship to express ɛm(β) but using a quadratic fit of the tabulated data by Owen and Rogers3 gives (7)Cw,ent=(0.2242β2-0.441β+0.219)Reφ0.8 For β=0 (free-disc) this gives the well-known result (8)Cw,ent=0.219Reφ0.8 For β=0.42 which corresponds to a rotor–stator system with Cw = 0 (9)Cw,ent=0.073Reφ0.8

Since β depends on λT, the above suggests there is no single value of ɛm that can be used to delineate the flow regime. However, for a superimposed radial outflow, a value of λT = 0.219 represents an upper limit to the value of ɛm and consequently an upper limit to a flow that is dominated by rotation effects.

The experiments conducted by Dibelius et al.5 used a test rig with a rotor disc in an enclosed housing. For rotor-mounted bolts, they noted a significant increase in the moment coefficient above that of a plain disc. This occurred for both zero superimposed flow and large values of superimposed flow. Also, they used the radial pressure gradient to derive an axial thrust term in order to demonstrate the effects of protrusions. Comparing the axial thrust values, they noticed that the effect of the protrusions on the flow structure was more pronounced when the flow was dominated by rotational effects.

Zimmerman et al.6 measured the effect of various bolt designs on shaft torque. Those considered were: staged (i.e. axially stacked concentric bolts of reducing diameter), cylindrical rotor bolts, partially covered and fully covered (by an annular ring) rotor bolts. It was found that 18 staged bolts on a disc at a radius ratio of rp/b = 0.75 increased the measured torque over the plain disc by a factor of 2.5, with further increases for cylindrical shaped bolts. Partially covered bolts gave little benefit in reducing the overall torque compared to the uncovered bolts. However, fully covered bolts gave a significant reduction in moment coefficient compared with the uncovered bolts and a moment coefficient of approximately 25% above that of a plain disc. The effect of a superimposed flow of Cw = 2.6 × 104 was to increase the moment coefficient by 50% for all the bolt designs investigated. The increase in moment coefficient due to the presence of rotor-mounted protrusions was attributed to the superposition of three elements: form drag, skin friction and pumping losses. They found that for a small (N ≤ 13) number of bolts, form drag dominates the additional moment produced, whereas for a large number of bolts the pumping losses become more important. In addition, the authors also suggest a theoretical limit where increasing the number of bolts will actually cause a decrease in the moment coefficient.

The experiments of Millward and Robinson7 measured enthalpy rise in the supplied flow. These were carried out by varying the number of bolts, their diameter, circumferential pitch and projected cross-sectional area. With bolts attached to both the rotorand the stationary casing, they obtained a correlation of their results for bolts attached to the rotor. They also noted that the effect on enthalpy rise of bolts located towards the outer radius was very significant, whereas those located towards the inner radius had little effect. For stator-mounted bolts, there was insufficient data to derive a correlation, but it was noted that the enthalpy rise due to stator bolts was about one-third of the corresponding conditions with rotor bolts. Tests were also carried out with full and partial covering of both stator and rotor bolts. No measurable effect was found by partially covering the rotor bolts but the stator bolts showed a reduction in enthalpy rise at high mass flows. Fully covered bolts, however, gave similar results to a plain disc and in some cases a reduction was actually observed.

Gartner8 developed a semi-empirical correlation that gives satisfactory agreement for the moment coefficient from a plain disc over a wide range of dimensionless mass flows. Gartner9 used a momentum integral method to predict the frictional torque from a single disc with protrusions. The predictions agree well with available data, provided the spacing between the bolts is not so small that wake effects become significant.

Coren10 carried out an experimental study on windage effects in rotor–stator cavities. Tests were carried out with bolts mounted on the rotor or on the stator. He suggested correlations for the moment coefficient as a function of the number, size and location of the bolts. Laser Doppler anemometry was also used to measure the radial and tangential components of velocity.

sec.title: The bolt windage test rig
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows a general assembly of the test rig. This consists of a shaft-mounted titanium alloy disc of outer radius b = 225 mm enclosed within a sealed steel pressure casing. The maximum clearance between the rotor and casing is s = 22 mm. Around the outer rim of the disc is a labyrinth seal and a stator-mounted shroud encases the cavities on either side of the disc. The disc is driven by a 50 kW motor through a 5:1 step-up gearbox. Mounted between the gearbox and the disc is an in-line torquemeter. The test side of the disc (labelled ‘front cavity’ in Figure 1) carries the majority of the instrumentation whereas the balance side (labelled ‘rear cavity’) has sufficient instrumentation to balance the flow conditions on both sides of the disc. A superimposed flow of air enters the rig centrally on the test side, flows radially outward through the cavity and leaves through the labyrinth seal at the perimeter. An equal amount of air is supplied to the balance side, where it enters through four inlet pipes equally spaced around the central shaft. There are four orifice plates positioned upstream and downstream of the test rig on both the test and balance side to measure the mass flow of air into and out of the rig and this ensures both sides are balanced. The air is supplied at pressures of up to 7.5 bar (absolute) and mass flows (to both sides) of up to 0.82 kg/s by an Atlas Copco screw-type compressor and treated with an Atlas Copco air-conditioning unit to provide dry air in the range of 15–25 ℃ prior to delivery to the rig. Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of the bolt windage test rig.

A shaft-mounted Vibrometer TM112 in line torquemeter measures torque and rotational speed. The 95% confidence interval in torque measurement is less than ± 1 N m. The uncertainty in speed measurement is less than ± 5 r/min. The torque due to bearing friction in the test rig depends on rotational speed and was obtained by a previous calibration. This driveline torque was subtracted from all of the measured values of torque to obtain a value of the torque transmitted to the fluid, M. The magnitude of the driveline torque varied from approximately 2% of the total at high rotational speeds to approximately 20% at low values of rotational speed.

It is important to note that the test rig was designed with the intention of making the torque on the test and balance sides equal. The two sides have the same geometrical configuration with bolts located on both sides of the disc at the same radius. Furthermore, the pressure was kept equal on both sides of the cavity to provide the same flow conditions. The cooling flow enters into the balance side at a much higher radius (r/b = 0.55) than that on the test side (r/b = 0.1). As a result, the flow travels over a smaller section of disc before exiting the system. There are two reasons why this difference in inlet radius is thought to have an insignificant effect on the torque. Firstly, the torque on a plain disc is a strong function of radius (M ∝ r).4,6 Consequently, most of the contribution to the torque experienced by the balance side comes from that radially outward of the inlet. Secondly, the tangential velocity of the disc at this higher radius will also be proportionally higher, leading to greater shear between the disc and non-rotating fluid near the entry point. This will increase the local moment coefficient in this region which will act to balance the torque experienced on each side of the disc.

Tests were carried out with N = 3, 9 and 18 and D = 16 mm, hexagonal bolts of height, H = 11 mm. These were attached, at a radius of 0.2 m, rb/b = 0.889, to both sides of the disc surface to ensure similar conditions on both sides and minimising axial heat conduction. For reference, the orientation of the bolts relative to the direction of rotation is shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Orientation of bolts with respect to rotation.

sec.title: Validation of the computational model
sec.p: Validation was performed against the plain disc experimental measurements of Coren10 carried out on the rotor–stator test rig described in the section ‘The bolt windage test rig’. The results of validation could be used for the more complex three-dimensional (3D) geometry of rotor–stator system with protrusions. However, the effects of 3D flow and the complex flow behaviour in the separation region behind bolts on the predictions of turbulence models are the places for further investigation.

No bolts were attached to either the rotor or the stator. The computations were carried out for two cases of interest: (1) throughflow-dominated (λT = 0.21, Cw = 0.3 × 105, Reφ = 0.271 × 107) and (2) rotationally dominated (λT = 0.09, Cw = 0.3 × 105, Reφ = 0.81 × 107). The absolute inlet air pressure and temperature for the throughflow-dominated case are 2.04 bar and 294 K, while for the rotationally dominated one, they are 3 bar and 301 K, respectively.

A schematic diagram of the geometry modelled is shown in Figure 3. Models of the geometry in 2D (two-dimensional) were built and meshed separately for use with enhanced wall and standard wall treatments. There is an extended geometry after the outlet which is used to avoid reversed flow through the outflow boundary. This extended geometry provides a uniform flow before the outlet boundary, and prevents it from changing direction and re-entry through the outlet, which could cause numerical instability. A grid independence study was carried out in order to make sure that the computational results were unaffected by grid size. To achieve this, the number of grid cells was doubled. Results were then compared with the coarser mesh. If the discrepancies between the two results were considered to be negligible, the coarser mesh was selected for further simulations. The number of points for the grid independent simulation in this case is 18,000 with 200 × 60 points in the r–z plane for use with the enhanced wall treatment and 9000 with 200 × 30 points in the r–z plane for use with the standard wall treatment. The segregated, implicit solver was used with the second-order discretisation method. Results were obtained using a number of different turbulence models so as to determine which provides the best match to the experimental data. Figure 3.
Schematic diagram of the two-dimensional simulated geometry.

The air is taken to be compressible with the ideal gas law for modelling density and Sutherland's law (three coefficient method) for modelling viscosity. The pressure and temperature boundary conditions used at the inlet for each case were obtained from the experimental data. The outlet pressure was set so that it produced the measured quantity of mass flow rate. A moving reference frame with an angular velocity of the rotor speed was used.

The convergence criteria were as follows.
Iterations residual for all the variables form a constant horizontal line and are less than 10−4.
The fluctuations of outlet mass flow rate are less than 0.1% of inlet mass flow rate.
All computed variables did not change significantly for at least 1000 iterations.

Figures 4 and 5 compare the simulation results of, respectively, the dimensionless radial and tangential velocities at r/b = 0.79 for the rotationally dominated case (λT = 0.09), using different turbulence models with the experimental data of Coren. Note that z/s = 0 corresponds to the rotor surface and z/s = 1 to the stator surface. Figures 6 and 7 show a comparison of similar results for the throughflow-dominated case (λT = 0.21). Figure 4.
Comparison of the axial distribution of dimensionless radial velocity for different turbulence models with the experimental data of Coren10 at r/b = 0.79, λT = 0.09, Cw = 0.3 × 105.
Note: z/s = 0 is located on the rotor. This is also the case for Figures 5 to 11.
Figure 5.
Comparison of axial distribution of dimensionless tangential velocity for different turbulence models with the experimental data of Coren10 at r/b = 0.79, λT = 0.09, Cw = 0.3 × 105.
Figure 6.
Comparison of the axial distribution of dimensionless radial velocity for different turbulence models with the experimental data of Coren10 at r/b = 0.79, λT = 0.21, Cw = 0.3 × 105.
Figure 7.
Comparison of the axial distribution of dimensionless tangential velocity for different turbulence models with the experimental data of Coren10 at r/b = 0.79, λT = 0.21, Cw = 0.3 × 105.

It can be seen from Figures 4 to 7 that there can be noticeable differences between the results obtained using the different turbulence models. The difference is more pronounced in the radial velocity distribution (Figures 4 and 6) and especially within the boundary layers. The results of the standard and realisable k–ɛ models are closer to the experimental data both for radial and tangential velocities. Results obtained using the Reynolds stress model (RSM) for tangential velocity show over-prediction of measured values. The same over-prediction also occurs in the computed value of the moment coefficient (see Table 1). While on average the RSM case requires about 50% more central processing unit (CPU) time in comparison to the k–ɛ and k–ω models, obtaining a converged solution for it was challenging even with reduced values of the under-relaxation factors. Reaching convergence was also difficult for the renormalisation group (RNG) model, and it generally resulted in a more unstable solution compared to the other models. The maximum number of iterations for achieving the stabilized solution for the two k–ɛ (standard and realisable) and the two k–ω (standard and shear stress transport (SST)) models was about 2500. However, for the RNG model, the solution was not stabilised even after about 8000 iterations. This could be due to the additional nonlinear terms in the governing equations of the RNG model. Compared with standard k–ɛ model, the additional terms in the ɛ-equation of the RNG model augment ɛ, reduce k and eventually the effective viscosity. This makes the RNG model to yield a lower turbulent viscosity in rapidly strained flows than the standard k–ɛ model. As a result, RNG model is subjected to instabilities in steady-state solutions in comparison with the standard k–ɛ model which is slightly over-diffusive and gives more stable solutions. Table 1.
Comparison of the moment coefficient results of different turbulence models with the experimental data of Coren10 (λT = 0.09, Cw = 0.3 × 105).
Model Cm (two sides)
k-ɛ – Standard 0.00686
k-ɛ – Realisable 0.00676
k-ɛ –RNG 0.00647
k-ω – Standard 0.0063
k-ω– SST 0.0066
RSM 0.0095
Experimental data – Coren10 0.0068
RNG: renormalisation group; SST: shear stress transport; RSM: Reynolds stress model.

Tables 1 and 2 compare the computed values of moment coefficient with the experimental measurements for λT = 0.09 and 0.21, respectively. The simulation results are generally in very good agreement with the experimental measurements. Furthermore, it can be seen that the results of different turbulence models (with the exception of the RSM model) show only a small discrepancy from each other. As a result, it can be concluded that the moment coefficient has low sensitivity to the selection of turbulence model. Table 2.
Comparison of the moment coefficient results of different turbulence models with the experimental data of Coren10 (λT = 0.21, Cw = 0.3 × 105).
Model Cm (two sides)
k-ɛ– Standard 0.0099
k-ɛ– Realisable 0.0098
k-ɛ – RNG 0.0093
k-ω- Standard 0.0089
k-ω – SST 0.0093
RSM 0.013
Experimental data – Coren10 0.010
RNG: renormalisation group; SST: shear stress transport; RSM: Reynolds stress model.

It is also worth commenting on the effect of near-wall treatments on the moment coefficient and velocity distributions. Using the enhanced wall treatment requires fine meshes near the walls, which increases the total number of points and, as a result, the CPU time for the simulation. Therefore, another mesh was generated for use with standard wall treatment. The effect of different near-wall treatments on the velocity distribution across the cavity at r/b = 0.79 is shown in Figures 8 to 11. The radial and tangential velocities for λT = 0.09 are shown in Figures 8 and 9, respectively, and those for λT = 0.21 in Figures 10 and 11, respectively. Two wall treatment schemes were used: standard wall function and enhanced wall treatment both with the k–ɛ turbulence model. For λT = 0.21, there is generally a good agreement between the two methods of wall treatment. Both schemes show separate boundary layer on the rotor and stator, separated by a core region where Vr = 0 and Vϕ/rω ≈ 0.2. Radial outflow occurs in the rotor boundary layer and radial inflow in the stator boundary layer. This is consistent with a qualitative description of the flow provided by Batchelor11 (Figures 10 and 11); there are significant differences between the radial velocities obtained from the two methods. However, there is very little difference in the tangential velocity. For the value of λT = 0.21, the flow structure is expected to be dominated by the throughflow rate and it can be seen to be in broad agreement with Stewartson's12 description. There is a boundary layer adjacent to the rotor with both radial and tangential velocity gradients and almost a zero tangential velocity everywhere outside of this boundary layer. A positive radial velocity exists between rotor and stator adjacent to the rotor; this is augmented due to the pumping effect of the rotor. In contrast, near the stator there is little or no evidence of a boundary layer. It can be seen from Figure 10 that the standard wall function approach fails to predict a negative radial velocity near the stator but the enhanced wall treatment gives results that are more consistent with the experimental data shown in Figure 6. This could be due to the modelling method of the near-wall region for the standard wall function, in which the viscosity-affected region is not resolved and is bridged by the wall function directly to the turbulent core. It appears from Figure 10 that the negative radial velocity region near the stator is not predicted by the standard wall function. This results in an over-prediction of radial velocity in that region and since the radial velocity continues to increase away from the stator, this over-prediction will accordingly continue across the whole width of the cavity. For λT = 0.09 (Figures 8 and 9) the disparity is less than for λT = 0.21 and only occurs close to the stator (z/s ≈ 1). Figure 8.
Simulation results of radial velocity at r/b = 0.79 for different near wall treatments, using the standard k–ɛ model, λT = 0.09, Cw = 0.3 × 105.
Figure 9.
Simulation results of tangential velocity at r/b = 0.79 for different near wall treatments, using the standard k–ɛ model, λT = 0.09, Cw = 0.3 × 105.
Figure 10.
Simulation results of radial velocity at r/b = 0.79 for different near wall treatments, using the standard k–ɛ model, λT = 0.21, Cw = 0.3 × 105.
Figure 11.
Simulation results of tangential velocity at r/b = 0.79 for different near wall treatments, using the standard k–ɛ model, λT = 0.21, Cw = 0.3 × 105.

Tables 3 and 4 show a comparison between the simulation results of moment coefficient for λT = 0.09 and λT = 0.21, respectively, the two using different near-wall treatments. It can be seen that the standard wall function gives a lower value of the moment coefficient (by about 8%) compared to the results from the enhanced wall treatment. This happens because the standard wall function does not model the details of the laminar sub-layer and the buffer layer regions, and hence fails to accurately predict the viscous losses in those areas. However, it is important to note that the number of points for the mesh using the enhanced wall treatment is approximately twice the number of points for standard wall function. This results in a threefold increase in CPU time required to reach convergence. Although not too significant for the above 2D computations, the increase in computational costs is expected to be more pronounced for the 3D simulations that include the bolts where finer grids are required around the bolt. In addition, it should be noted that when the bolts are modelled, the effect of the pressure difference around the bolts is the main mechanism for torque production. Typically, the pressure field is not very sensitive to the different types of wall treatment. Consequently, and in the interest of computational efficiency, the standard wall function was chosen as the near-wall treatment for modelling the 3D bolt windage data. Table 3.
Comparison of moment coefficient for different near wall treatments, using the standard k–ɛ model (λT = 0.09, Cw = 0.3 × 105).
Model Cm (two sides)
Standard k-ɛ, enhanced wall treatment 0.0068
Standard k-ɛ, standard wall function 0.0064
Experimental data, Coren10 0.0068
Table 4.
Comparison of moment coefficient for different near wall treatments, using the standard k–ɛ model (λT = 0.21, Cw = 0.3 × 105).
Model Cm (two sides)
Standard k-ɛ, enhanced wall treatment 0.0099
Standard k-ɛ, standard wall function 0.009
Experimental data, Coren10 0.01

Based on the results gathered in this validation exercise, it would appear that the standard k–ɛ model offers the best combination of computational accuracy combined with simplicity of use. In addition, it was found that the moment coefficient and the tangential velocity distribution have a relatively low sensitivity to the selection of turbulence model. Since those parameters are the main outputs of the simulations, the use of more complex models like SST–k–ω or RSM will not provide significant advantages. As a result, the standard k–ɛ turbulence model was chosen for the 3D simulations.

sec.title: Computational fluid dynamics simulations of rotor-mounted bolts
sec.p: As mentioned in the section ‘The bolt windage test rig’, the bolt windage rig has a double-sided disc and the experiments were carried out by balancing the flow to both sides. Balancing the test (front) and balance (rear) sides of the cavity was achieved by matching the mass flow together with the inlet and outlet pressures. As well as reducing the net axial load on the rotor, this also ensures minimum leakage at the peripheral seals between the front and rear sides of the disc. Consequently, it is possible to simulate one side of the cavity in isolation to reduce the mesh size by 50%.

In order to confirm that very little leakage occurred in the experiment, a plain disc two-sided model was simulated under four different conditions (Reφ=2.7×106,5.78×106,8.02×106 and11.7×106 with Cw = 0.3 × 105 (0.063 < λT < 0.21)). Figure 12 shows the simulated geometry of the two-sided cavity. Figure 12.
Schematic diagram of the two-sided simulated geometry.

The total viscous moment coefficient of the disc can be divided into three sources: one from the front side of the disc, the other from the rear side of the disc and another from the peripheral seal. Figure 13 shows the contributions of these sources of moment coefficient to the total for the four different rotational Reynolds numbers simulated. It can be seen that the moment coefficient of the front and rear sides are almost the same. This is also shown in Figure 14 which gives the percentage contribution of each component to the total moment coefficient. It is relevant to note that the moment coefficient for the peripheral seal is generally around 10% of the total moment coefficient (or one-ninth of the value obtained from the two disc surfaces). Figure 13.
Contribution to the total moment coefficient produced by the different rotating components in the simulated two-sided plain disc geometry, Cw = 0.3 × 105.
Figure 14.
Contribution of the different rotating components in the simulated two-sided plain disc geometry, Cw = 0.3 × 105.

This fact is used in subsequent computations where just one side of the cavity is modelled. The peripheral seal is not modelled, but the contribution to the total moment coefficient shows little significant variation with Reφ and is not expected to vary with Cw. The experimentally measured values of the moment coefficient take account of the frictional torques experienced on both sides of the disc and the peripheral seal. So, computed values from a one-sided model of the cavity can be compared with the experimental values by doubling the computed values of Cm and then adding 11% of this value to represent the contribution of the peripheral seal.

Figure 15 shows part of the mesh used in the 3D computational model for the bolt windage test rig. The periodic boundaries of the sector modelled lie mid-way between the bolts. So for three bolts a 120° sector is used, for nine bolts a 40° sector and for 18 bolts a 20° sector. There is an extended geometry at the outlet, and a pipe attached to the inlet. Unstructured grids were used in the r–φ plane only. Finer grids are used near the bolt. The distances near the walls were specified to allow the use of the standard wall treatment. The standard k–ɛ model was used for simulations. Figure 15.
A section of the computational mesh used for the bolt windage test rig.

Two different flow conditions Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 (λT = 0.35) and Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 (λT = 0.09) were used in this article. The former corresponds to a throughflow-dominated regime and the later a regime where rotational effects are expected to dominate. Other dimensional parameters are given in Table 5. While both the disc and the bolts are rotating with a constant angular speed in a moving fluid, it is easier to look at the fluid in the relative frame. Table 5.
Simulated flow conditions of the bolt windage rig 3D case.
m· (kg/s) Reϕ Cw λT ω (rad/s) Pin (bar) Tin (K)
Flow condition 1 0.415 6.8 × 106 105 0.35 409.5 5.1 297
Flow condition 2 0.119 7.2 × 106 0.3 × 105 0.09 902.5 3 292

Figures 16 and 17, respectively, illustrate the velocity streamlines around the bolt on a cross-sectional plane at z/s = 0.045 for three bolts and for Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 and Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105. It can be seen that the flow has both radial and tangential velocity components hitting the bolt with a non-zero angle of attack and brought to rest at the stagnation point. From the stagnation point, pressure is transferred into kinetic energy and the boundary layer develops under a negative pressure gradient. This can be seen in Figure 18 which shows the pressure distribution around the bolt where equation (10) was used to calculate the pressure coefficient (10)Cp=(ps-p∞)1/1 2 2ρV2 where ps is the static pressure, p∞ is the free-stream pressure and V is the free-stream velocity magnitude. Figure 16.
Velocity streamlines around the bolts for N = 3 (Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 and λT = 0.35) at z/s = 0.045.
Figure 17.
Velocity streamlines around the bolts for N = 3 (Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 and λT = 0.09) at z/s = 0.045.
Figure 18.
Pressure distribution around the bolts for N = 3 at z/s = 0.045.

The pressure reduction continues up to a point at which the pressure reaches a minimum and after that the boundary layer develops with a positive or adverse pressure gradient. As the fluid decelerates in the adverse pressure region, its kinetic energy is transferred into pressure. The pressure increases up to a point at which the velocity gradient becomes zero. At this point, the flow encounters separation where the momentum of fluid cannot overcome the adverse pressure gradient. Here the boundary layer detaches from the bolt, the fluid is pushed backward by the pressure gradient and a wake region is formed. This region is the source of the form drag of the bolt and is characterised by vortex formation.

The important parameters affecting the flow structure and the pressure distribution around the bolt are the free-stream Reynolds number, ReD (equation11) and the angle of attack α (equation 12). For the flow approaching the bolt on a cross-sectional plane at z/s = 0.045, the angle of attack and free-stream Reynolds number are, respectively, α = −12° and ReD = 1.8 × 105 for Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 and α = −20° and ReD = 1.47 × 105 for Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 (11)ReD=ρVrelDμ (12)α=tan-1(VrVϕ-rel) where Vr, Vϕ−rel and Vrel are the radial, relative tangential and relative free-stream velocities and D is the bolt's diameter.

Variation of the rotational and throughflow Reynolds numbers lead to variation in the radial and relative tangential velocity distributions and as a result the relative velocity magnitude of the flow approaching the bolts. Relative velocity magnitude, which is the vector sum of radial and relative tangential velocities, is itself a function of radial, tangential and axial locations in the cavity. Hence, the only method to find the free-stream velocity in equation (11) is to average the relative velocity magnitude over a plane downstream the bolt.

For a cylinder and a sphere, increasing the relative velocity of the fluid and hence the free-stream Reynolds number decreases both the wake region area and the form drag of the body.13 Considering the angle of attack, Schlichting13 found that both the pressure distribution and the lift coefficient are dependent on the angle of attack. According to his measurements for a NACA 4412 airfoil at constant Reynolds number, increasing the angle of attack from α = 0° to α = 8° changes the symmetric pressure distribution to a significantly different pressure profile at upper and lower sides. Also, it increases the lift coefficient to about three times more than the one for α = 0°.

Figures 19 and 20 show the entropy contours around bolts at z/s = 0.045 for the two mentioned flow conditions. The wake regions are known to have the highest values of entropy due to the rapid and irregular fluctuations of flow. Comparing the shape of the wakes in Figures 19 and 20, it can be seen that decreasing the throughflow causes the wakes to become more circumferential in its path around the bolt. Also, a decrease in λT causes an increase in the wake shed from the trailing edge of one bolt with the leading edge of the next which reduces the area of the wake region and consequently the amount of form drag. Figure 19.
Entropy contours (J/kg K) around the bolts for N = 3 (Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 and λT = 0.35) at z/s = 0.045.
Figure 20.
Entropy contours (J/kg K) around the bolts for N = 3 (Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 and λT = 0.09) at z/s = 0.045.

Clarifying the critical parameters affecting the flow structure around the bolts, it is now possible to investigate how the flow structure varies by increasing the number of bolts in the system. Figures 21 and 22 illustrate the entropy contours on a cross-sectional plane at z/s = 0.045 using 9, 18, 45 and 60 bolts for Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 (λT = 0.35) and Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 (λT = 0.09). It is apparent that the form of the wake changes with the number of bolts fitted to the rotor. Increasing the number of bolts (and decreasing the distance between the two neighbouring bolts) can lead to a situation where the wake of one bolt has not fully collapsed in advance of the following bolt. Also for N ≥18 the wake falls on the upper section of the bolt. Figure 21.
Entropy contours (J/kg K) around the bolts for N = 9, 18, 45 and 60 (Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 and λT = 0.35) at z/s = 0.045.
Figure 22.
Entropy contours (J/kg K) around the bolts for N = 9, 18, 45 and 60 (Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 and λT = 0.09) at z/s = 0.045.

The effect of the number of bolts on the axial variation of dimensionless tangential velocity at r/b = 0.9 is illustrated in Figures 23 and 24 for the two flow conditions investigated in Figures 16–22. The horizontal axis starts at z/s = 0.42 which corresponds to the axial location of the tip of the bolt. The tangential velocity varies around the circumference of the bolt radius and the value used in these graphs is that obtained at the location of the centreline of the bolt. Figure 23.
Predicted axial variation of dimensionless tangential velocity at r/b = 0.9, Reφ = 6.8 × 106 and Cw = 105 (λT = 0.35).
Note: z/s = 0 is located on rotor. This is also the case for Figure 23.
Figure 24.
Predicted axial variation of dimensionless tangential velocity at r/b = 0.9, Reφ = 7.2 × 106 and Cw = 0.3 × 105 (λT = 0.09).

It is clear from Figures 23 and 24 that the presence of bolts on the rotor brings about an increase in the tangential velocity of the core (Vφ/rω). Although increasing N generally increases Vφ/rω, there is a levelling off (as was noticed in the value of Cm referred to above). It is also interesting to note that the plain disc (N = 0) values of Vφ/ωr for λT = 0.35 and λT = 0.09 are quite different (Vφ/rω ≈ 0.04 and 0.3, respectively). This discrepancy reduces with the presence of bolts. In the limit of N = 60, Vφ/rω ≈ 0.8 for both λT = 0.35 and λT = 0.09.

As mentioned previously, increasing the number of bolts causes an increase in the tangential velocity of the fluid approaching the bolt and hence a reduction in its relative tangential velocity. Although the radial velocity also increases with increasing N, its variation is significantly lower than the variation in relative tangential velocity. As a result, the effect of increasing N is to decrease the free-stream Reynolds number and increase the angle of attack of the fluid approaching the bolt (see equations 11 and 12).

It is also important to investigate how the pressure distribution varies around bolt by adding more bolts into the system. It was found that increasing the number of bolts increases the peak of the total pressure but also decreases the relative total pressure difference across each individual bolt. This is due to the increased influence of wakes from upstream bolts producing a smaller pressure difference across the bolt.

Describing the flow structure and different parameter variations around the bolts, it is possible to investigate how these variations affect the power loss in the system by calculating the bolts moment coefficient.

Figures 25 and 26 show the moment coefficient variation (on one side of the disc) with number of bolts N for Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 (λT = 0.35) and Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 (λT = 0.09). The experimental results, together with those from the computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations, are shown for N = 3, 9 and 18 bolts as well as for a plain disc. As it can be seen, there is a good overall agreement between the predictions and experimental data and this gives confidence in the numerical model. Results of the moment coefficient for plain disc can also be compared with the correlation suggested by Coren14 (13)Cm={0.52[Cw]0.37[Reϕ]-0.57+0.0028}/2 Figure 25.
Variation of moment coefficient with number of bolts N. Comparison between numerical and experimental results for 3, 9 and 18 bolts and also a plain disc: Reφ = 6. 8 × 106, Cw = 105 (λT = 0.35).
Figure 26.
Variation of moment coefficient with number of bolts N. Comparison between numerical and experimental results for 3, 9 and 18 bolts and also a plain disc: Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 (λT = 0.09).

Using his correlation, the moment coefficient of the plain disc for Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 is 0.0037 and for Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 is 0.0028. Comparing these values with those obtained by the experimental and numerical results, it can be found that his correlation underestimates the moment coefficient.

Figures 27 and 28 show the variation of moment coefficient with the number of bolts N = 3, 9, 18, 36, 45, 60 (for N = 60, the circumferential spacing between one bolt and the next is less than D/4) and a continuous ring was used with 16 mm radial thickness and 11 mm height at r = 0.2 m on the rotor for Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 (λT = 0.35) and Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 (λT = 0.09). It can be seen that, not surprisingly, the presence of bolts causes a significant rise in the moment coefficient above that of a plain disc and increasing N also increases Cm. Furthermore, it can be seen that the moment coefficient of the throughflow-dominated case (Figure 27) is significantly higher than that of the rotationally dominated cases (Figure 28). The reason for this is that increasing throughflow brings about a decrease in the tangential velocity of the core region. This occurs due to conservation of angular momentum and is a well-known phenomenon in a plain disc rotor–stator cavity3 and as it was shown, it is also true in a rotor–stator system with rotor-mounted bolts. Consequently, the relative (rotor to core) tangential velocity is increased by an increase in superimposed flow and this leads to an increase in the moment coefficient due to an increase in skin friction. Figure 27.
Predicted variation of moment coefficient with number of bolts N for Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 (λT = 0.35).
Figure 28.
Predicted variation of moment coefficient with number of bolts N for Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 (λT = 0.09).

There also appears to be a value of N for which Cm remains relatively unaffected by further increase in the number of bolts. For λT = 0.35, this occurs when N = 50 and for λT = 0.09 when N = 20. It is interesting to see in Figures 18 and 19 that the moment coefficient of the ring is approximately equal to the moment coefficient of a plain disc. This is in agreement with the investigations of Millward and Robinson.

As it was mentioned earlier in this article, the skin friction is reduced as λT decreases. Also increasing the number of bolts reduces the area and causes an increase in the wake shed from the trailing edge of one bolt with the leading edge of the next. This also causes a reduction in Cm through the mechanism of form drag. There is also the (reversible) loss associated with the pumping mechanism of the bolts. It would be of interest to further investigate the contribution to Cm. However, since FLUENT reports only the viscous moment and pressure moment (which includes both the moment produced by the wakes and by pumping action) separately, it is not possible to find the amount of moment produced by the wakes alone. As mentioned, increasing the number of bolts decreases the relative total pressure difference across each individual bolt. This leads to a net decrease in the moment. However, since there are more bolts, the contribution of pressure-related moment of all bolts increases together.

The above results are summarised in Figures 29 and 30. This provides the contribution of skin friction and pressure-related (form drag and radial pumping) contributions to the overall moment coefficient for the two flow conditions. It is clear that the skin friction contributes less to the overall moment coefficient than the pressure does. As shown in Figures 29 and 30, the dominance of the pressure-related moment means that the net effect of increasing the number of bolts is to increase the overall moment coefficient. But for the reasons explained above concerning the structure of the wakes, the rate at which Cm increases with N, decreases as N becomes larger. Figure 29.
Variation of the overall moment coefficient, viscous and pressure-related (form drag and radial pumping) contributions with number of bolts (Reφ = 6.8 × 106 and Cw = 105 and λT = 0.35).
Figure 30.
Variation of the overall moment coefficient, viscous and pressure-related (form drag and radial pumping) contributions with number of bolts (Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 and λT = 0.09).

It is also interesting to study the flow structure variations in the z-direction in order to investigate the occurrence of Taylor columns. Taylor columns were observed by Farthing15 during his measurements. He performed experimental measurements inside a rotating cavity with four cylindrical protrusions and radial outflow of air. According to his observations, Taylor columns can be produced in the system. Taylor columns are imaginary cylinders projected above and below the real cylinder in a steady flow with strong rotations. According to Taylor–Proudman theorem, the flow will curve around this cylinder and the directional derivative of velocity in the direction of the axis of rotation will vanish. Since the existence of strong rotation is necessary for producing the Taylor columns, Rossby number equation (14) can be used as an indicator. (14)Ro=1-Vϕrω

Rossby number ranges from 0.98 for plain disc to 0.27 for 60 bolts for the flow condition of Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 and from 0.74 for plain disc to 0.14 for 60 bolts for Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105. According to these ranges of Rossby number, there is an intermediate rotation for the two flow conditions for all the number of bolts used in the system (except for the 60 bolts under the rotationally dominated condition). As a result, it is expected that no Taylor column will be produced in the system. This is confirmed by the simulation results.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article has presented CFD predictions of the flow in a rotor–stator cavity with a superimposed radial flow. The aim has been to investigate the effect on the moment coefficient and velocity distributions of varying the number of bolts on the rotor. This has been achieved by using a number of different 2D and 3D CFD models and the commercial code FLUENT.

A 2D CFD model was used for validation against experimental data and also to investigate the sensitivity of the CFD results to the choice of turbulence model and wall treatment scheme. Although not the most accurate, a standard k–ɛ turbulence model with a standard wall treatment was selected for the 3D computations as a compromise due to practical limitations in the CPU time. The test rig comprises a rotor in a pressurised casing supplied with air. The outer radius of the rotor is b = 0.225 m and the axial gap between the rotor and casing is 0.022 m.

Two (3D) test cases were used to examine the effects of rotor-mounted bolts: One corresponds to a regime where rotation will dominate the flow structure: Reφ = 7.2 × 106, Cw = 0.3 × 105 (λT = 0.09); and the other where the flow is expected to be dominated by the superimposed radial flow Reφ = 6.8 × 106, Cw = 105 (λT = 0.35). Simulations were carried out for N = 3, 9, 18, 36, 45, 60 (for N = 60, the circumferential spacing between one bolt and the next is less than D/4) and a continuous ring with 16 mm radial thickness and 11 mm height at r = 0.2 m on the rotor.

It was found that increasing the number of bolts will decrease the relative total pressure difference around each individual bolt. Also, increasing N increases the tangential velocity of the fluid approaching the bolt and decreases its relative tangential velocity. This will result in an increase in the angle of attack and a decrease in the free-stream Reynolds number.
In addition, it was found that for all of the number of bolts mounted on the rotor and under the two flow conditions, no Taylor column will be produced in the system.

There appears to be very little difference between the values of Cm obtained for a plain disc with those for a continuous ring. Increasing the number of bolts creates an increase in the moment coefficient. However, this reaches a limit where further increases in N do not bring about an increase in Cm. This can be explained by examining the separate contributions that skin friction and pressure-related drag make to the overall moment coefficient. The skin friction actually reduces as the number of bolts is increased. This is because increasing N causes the tangential velocity of the core to increase which decreases the relative rotor-to-core velocity. The pressure-related drag (it was not possible to discriminate between form drag and pumping loss in this study) is also affected by increasing N. The more bolts fitted, the more the wake of the leading bolt affects that of the bolt immediately behind. As a result, the drag for each bolt is reduced, but as there are more bolts, the overall drag increases. The direction of the wake shed by one bolt and therefore its influence on another bolt is also found to be affected by λT. A small value of λT will reduce the moment coefficient since the wake shed from one bolt becomes more circumferential and incident with the leading edge of another. Conversely, a large value of λT causes the wake to become more radial since there is less shielding between one bolt and the next. As a result, the moment coefficient will increase with increasing λT and decrease with decreasing λT.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: Funding was provided by Rolls-Royce PLC for the experimental work used for the validation of the CFD computations.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.

def.p: inner and outer radii of the disc, respectively
total, static and free-stream pressure, respectively
axial gap between rotor and stator
radial, tangential and free-stream velocities in a stationary coordinate system
